reviewText:
A fantastic throwback surprise. A modern work in authentic NES style game design. Simplistic, stylistic, atmospheric. At times peaceful and relaxing, at times frustrating and intense. Fight your own logic as much as the featured slope jump mechanics as you work your way through a world that speaks very little and lets you embrace a childhood sense of imagination, fervor, and challenge. It's charming, with a top notch, catchy, addictive soundtrack. First playthrough was a little over 5 hrs to completion. Short? Perhaps it's not that the game is too short, but rather that I really wanted more once I finished. I would like to see more diverse enemies in a future expansion or sequel. 5 dollars well spent.

Steam player synopsis:
Fell far.
Lived.
Threw fireballs.
Blobs died.
Jumped high.
Spinning death trap.
Walked in grass.
Falling spike trap.
Walked in more grass.
Appearing spike trap.
Double jumped across a chasm.
Floated like a tanooki suited Mario.
Missed ledge.
Fell in Spikes...wasn't a trap.
Just spikes.
Died to many Spikes.
Enjoyed it.
Alot.

Retro review: Would jump into spikes again.

reviewText:
Came looking for a good or at least DECENT metroidvania, instead found:

-No health: You die in one hit
-Bad jump controls: You rocket jump straight upwards the exact same height whenever you push the jump button, no matter how briefly, and especially when you don't want to go that high, except that sometimes you don't for no apparent reason.
-Fundamentally broken level design: In the first FOUR SCREENS of the game there are no less than four arbitrary spike traps that kill the player upon trying to step onto a certain area of ground, with absolutely NO warning whatsoever, no graphical hint or clue that there even MIGHT be anything than normal ground there. Other spikes are placed in such a way that moving from one screen into another that the player has NEVER been to before can get the player killed because they didn't enter from the right side or decided to jump.

If you're looking for what I was looking for, do not buy this game. If you are looking for anything resembling a GOOD high-difficulty game, do not buy this game. I want to un-buy this game. The fact that I can say all of this with so little playtime behind me and COMPLETE confidence should tell you everything you need to know.

reviewText:
It's hard for all the wrong reasons
- when you change screen, you often fall in a trap (that you couldn't foresee) : insta death.
- when you jump somewhere, there is often an (invisible) trap: insta death.
The only way to pass a level is by memorizing it. And not by skill. You've got to die a few times to know where are the traps and then you can go through the level.

Then the game got even more difficult (for more unfair reasons) and I abandoned it.

reviewText: While the game seems unforgiving at first it's actually a great game with lots of old school mechanics, sonic and games of that sort were built and thrived off of this sort of gameplay, memorize the levels, perfect your movements and progress in the game. I would definitely recommend this game to people who like a challenge.\n\nOne thing I would love to see for this game is controller support.

reviewText: Only played a little bit so far and although it's hard as nails, there is that satisfaction of getting to the next screen that you've been trying for 10 minutes to do. Fitting music and cute art make it less frustrating when things go wrong. I imagine things will be less painful when I start unlocking some of the specials.\n\nWill update this review after I've played a little more, so far it's a worthy purchase.
